values: For the record, when on Monday at around noon I noticed that my car had disappeared from my parking spot, I: a) Checked the other spots, the street, and the side-streets to make sure it hadn't been moved. b) Called my landlord to make sure it hadn't been towed, but couldn't get him because it was a holiday weekend. c) Called the towing company used by my landlord, and then all of the other towing companies in town. d) Called the police. e) Called GEICO. f) Talked over the theft with C, A, and R (...in that order! funny coincidence) who convinced me that I shouldn't have been quite so insistent, in statements to the police and insurance agent, that my car door had been unlocked. g) Called the police and insurer back to explain that I didn't know what had come over me when I'd said the door had been unlocked, I must have been casting around in my mind for something that would explain the shocking randomness of the theft. i) Called my parents to explain what had happened to my car (actually my mother's car). My mother said, "Other than the car being stolen, how was your weekend?" j) Was consoled by R and C (lol), who said I'd save a lot of money on gas and insurance and reminded me that New Brunswick is on the Northeast Corridor. Then, and ONLY then, did I post a quick note to twitter. I know the web is full of twitter addicts but come on, give me a little credit! So that's this week's bad news. The good news is that Pearson HR took my side in a hearing this morning. (Long story.) Hope you all have been doing well. I've been working as an office manager for my dad in New York by day, taking graduate-level statistics courses by night. And falling asleep over my coffee every morning, XD.
I leave you with this.

1. Back from Europe! As of last Monday, but ran around for a week between New Jersey, New York, and Upstate New York. Moved out of my parents' place and into an apartment last Wednesday - so easy, all the furniture was there already and I was able to transfer my suitcase from Europe without unpacking it - Chrissie is the best roommate ever. :D Funny, good listener, supposedly too lazy to cook or clean but keeps food under wraps with the dedication of someone who has lived in a tropical country where the cockroaches are the size of small cats. We have lots of sauces and fresh vegetables, and two of every sized skillet, but there were no duplicates when we combined our video game collections - which is what REALLY matters, am I right? Going to be carless starting in August (long story) so I went shopping today and was able to buy lots of July 4th things, like corn, watermelon, mustard and cherries, etc at discount. European/Central Asian spices were expensive but I tell myself it's for a good cause, ie now that I've bought them I'll have to actually cook with them. I also went "shopping" at home - took a plastic bag, my parents didn't really need that much seltzer water anyway. As for the Forth, I did the traditional thing and picniced. Twice! *g* At the picnic on Saturday, we got our British host to explain cricket to us. Turns out he was at Glastonbury* in the late 60s/early 70s: not just there, but there as a performer! In some band called Big Dick and the Scandals, with a "sister" band called Beryl and the Perils. XD; This thing about all-male acts with associated all-female acts, it's kind of like fraternities and sororities? At the picnic on Sunday, there was another guy who had been to Glastonbury this year - not for the music festival, but to see the magic stone circle. Glastonbury has a reputation as a Hippy gathering, like Woodstock, but when you can actually dance around a magic stone circle it takes the New Age vibe to a whole new level I think. *As you might have gathered, this is a major British music festival. There was scandal when Jay-Z headlined last year, ostensibly because he's not "rock" enough. In acknowledgment, he wore a guitar as a necklace. *** 2. Although the first few paragraphs of this entry were about the apartment, tonight will be only my second night here since coming back to the US. Spent July 4 with my parents and the rest of the nights with... did I mention that I've been seeing someone? A girl? Since May. She's amazing. ^^ Thinking about it, the reason it's easy to be out with R** is that when I'm with her I genuinely don't care what other people think. (Do I sound happy? I'm really, really happy. And why not? No job, new apartment, enough money for rent and to buy train tickets to/dinner in NYC, a girl with principles...) **Though as I remember I was out to some of you guys back in college, but not acting on it. So I guess this makes it official: I'm out! *** 3. Pictures from Europe are up on my brother's facebook - same last name, and his first name is Alex. All of them are public, I'm just trying to maintain some semblance of web propriety by not linking this journal to my real name too obviously. Here's a decent one of me: And one of him that I like because it reminds me of when we were kids and I was still taller than him: I had to stand on a 4-foot wall to take that picture.

Sitting in the office with no work - and I mean legitimately no work, not that there could be work if only I would apply myself more - so I am going to catch up this LJ with recent events. Quickly, before the headache from squinting at the screen with just one contact lens on sets in! (Will be picking up a new pair of glasses on my way home from work today. Thick black plastic-framed hipster glasses, very exciting!) First thing is that I was out of town last weekend - Portland/Portsmouth/Boston/NYC. In Portland (the one in Maine) on Friday my mother and I did the arts district in the morning, port district in the afternoon. We had lunch at a pub where we were the only women - sort of funny, the "commercial street pub" sign outside was right next to one that said "no drinking at any time" - getting into the spirit of the place we drank beer, and my mother told me about the summer she'd worked as a waitress at a Maine resort in the seventies. (What am I going to be able to tell my hypothetical children?!) Art district: really decent work at the Maine College of Art - acronym MECA - plastic flamingos dressed up in regional costumes. Also a nice antique fabric gallery across the street whose minder, who was about 25 and very friendly, said he'd gone to NYU and hadn't liked it because everyone was off doing their own thing, "like in high school" (which made me wonder what kind of high school he'd gone to). Port district: lots of lobster-flavored souvenirs and some old houses with plaques on 'em, including one called "Victoria House" that had Greek doric columns, Victorian woodwork around the doors and windows, Moorish geometric patterns along one roof, Chinese-style eaves along the other, and even a tower with one of those round nautical windows. All executed in brownstone. It was Special. *g* ...that paragraph could have been accomplished much more easily with pictures! Oh well. Dinner in Portsmouth, which turns out to be a really trendy, upscale place. (Who knew?) We went to three breweries in a row that each had a 45 minute wait, then finally scored at an older, smaller one where the staff said the wait was only 15 minutes...though this turned out to also be 45 minutes. XD; Proof that you shouldn't always settle for the first decent, easy thing? Did Boston Saturday. Met up with my cousin and her boyfriend, who have an apartment in Cambridge halfway between Harvard and MIT. Was nice to ditch the parents! We walked around Harvard Square, had lunch in a cafe where the waitress snootily informed us that they didn't serve those kinds of sodas (ie, Diet Coke - I suppose they had Italian sodas). Very good food though. Walked down to the Charles river, the weather was gorgeous, the people were wearing a variety of things - unlike New Yorkers, Bostonians don't tend to follow a style code. Boyfriend pointed out the building where he has a day job creating spreadsheets calculating the economic advantages of green technologies, on those rare days when his advisor is actually around to advise him. Discussed, with cousin, the way that office work trains you to approach every problem with "I can put that in a spreadsheet for you". Then tea in a coffee house where my cousin had work up (she paints), then MIT where we saw the building that might collapse. A bit dizzying, actually, to behold. According to cousin's bf the more architecturally complicated, the higher the costs of repairs. And the roof leaks, also. *g* Proceeded to browse at the MIT bookstore where every book is a ground-breaking study with good cover design - just skimming the titles made me feel smarter. Caught a train at 4:30 to NYC so I'd be back in time for Glasvegas, who were...not very good, actually. XD; Sort of boring? When your aesthetic ideal is a Phil Spectre-esque Wall of Sound, you'd better have the sound production to back it up, and they just didn't. Closed with what felt like the the entire audience singing along to this song, though, so that was a highlight. If I ever go to see this band again, I am definitely standing front and center - I'm not letting myself be taken aside after two drinks by a 40 year-old Morrissey fan who offers to buy me a third. (Seriously, what was I thinking? Though this did answer the question, who likes Glasvegas? As dude was way up on his British indie rock canon as determined by weekly British music magazines.) (Another nice thing about the show is that the audience was actually pretty mixed - old folk, young folk, black folk, white folk, Asian folk. Even some South Asian folk, who I have never before seen at an indie show.)

In other words, conversations with him are no longer horrendously awkward, not that they have been recently, but the possibility always seemed to be lurking around the edges of every conversation, and now it no longer seems to be. So I think he's going to be okay. So, news! The biggest piece of news is that I have a new job. ^_^v I'm working at Pearson Prentice Hall as the assistant to the senior editor in charge of humanities (History, English, Psychology, Art History, etc) textbook development. Although in fact, Rochelle is frequently not in the office, and I am more like the department's assistant. Everyone at Pearson has been very nice to me (especially Susanna, who told me I was "born to be a development editor," whatever that means) and I really enjoy my job there. The only awkward thing has been having my own office -- which is AWESOME, don't get me wrong, I love my office, but the other editorial assistants all have cubicals right next to each other, which has made it a little bit hard for me to casually make friends with them. If I want to be friends, I have to go out of my way. At any rate, after putting in some effort I'm now friendly enough with the other assistants to eat with them at the cafeteria -- that is if they ever ate lunch at the cafeteria, WHICH THEY DON'T. They either eat at their desks or go out to eat. ;_; The road to office friendship is a long one, full of difficulties. At the moment, I'm eating lunch with a group of 20-something accountants. They're very friendly, and very easy to talk to. I'm working at Pearson three days a week, and no longer working at the library or the bookstore. (I'm still working as a Math tutor.) At first I thought I'd take it easy and enjoy my time off, but now I'm starting to feel restless. And so, following the same tactics I succeeded with six months ago, I've been applying to local independent and chain bookstores. ("Local" judged by whether or not the college radio station still comes in at the parking lot.) So far, I haven't gotten a single call back -- apparently it's harder to find retail work in March in the middle of a recession. (Who knew?) If I can't find bookstore work, I'll probably go back to doing transcript summaries for District One, but I'll probably walk to the Rutgers student center to do them, first because the exercise will be good for me, second because the weather is really nice and it would be a shame not to take advantage of it, third because sitting at home is lonely, and fourth because I can NEVER get anything done at the house. How does anyone manage to work from home? How does Rochelle manage it? While I was still working at the bookstore and the library, I made some posts about it (under filter) at the other journal. Now that I am no longer working there, I might transfer the content over here. ...Well? Would anyone be interested? The last bit of news is that I went to Philadelphia to see Julie on Thursday. She seemed to be bearing up well, but told the nurse that her head was a 7 (out of 10, in terms of pain)! I never would have guessed. I guess she's had a rough semester and hasn't done as well as she would have liked, plus she has The Misogynist Instructor From Hell for a subjectively-graded, required-to-graduate course, which sucks. >_> Good luck, Julie! I hope you're all doing well!

I've had a stroke of genius and decided that since I'm working in a used bookstore, all of you are getting a book for Christmas. It's easy! It's cheap! (No more than $4 plus shipping per gift.) And most importantly, the bookstore is full of absolutely hysterical gems like American slang in letzer minute, a German "learn informal American English" book that has slang on one side of the page and a standard English translation on the other, like this:
SLANG Harry: What the fuck is wrong with you? You just drove your wreck into my Benz! Ron: Watch your mouth, bud. This car is worth a fortune. Harry: Gimme a break. This lemon isn't worth shit. I hope you got insurance, cause I'm gonna sue your pants off. Ron: Oh, I've got goosebumps, shortie. Harry: All right, that did it. Now I'm mad as hell. Nobody fucks with me and gets away with it. Put 'em up, asshole, cause I'm gonna give you a fat lip. Or maybe you'd prefer a black eye. Ron: Now you're talking, but I'll be the one dishing out black eyes and real doozies. I'm not chicken. Harry: Will ya be so cocky when I kick your ass, you little fucker? STANDARD ENGLISH Harry: What (anger!) is wrong with you? You just drove your old, broken-down car into my Mercedes Benz! Ron: Don't talk like that, fellow. This car is worth a lot of money. Harry: Stop talking such nonsense. This poor-quality car is worthless. I hope you have insurance, because I'm going to sue you for all your money. Ron: Oh, I'm scared, short person. Harry: All right, you've said too much. Now I'm extremely angry. Nobody bothers me and goes without punishment. Put up your fists and fight, idiot, because I'm going to hit you in the mouth. Or maybe you'd prefer a bruised eye. Ron: Now I agree with you, but I'll be the one giving people bruised eyes and really impressive ones. I'm not afraid. Harry: Will you be so bold and confident when I give you a good beating, you little idiot?
The absolute best part is that the book is divided between "street" (city) slang and "suburbs" (what those crazy kids are saying) slang. The street section is full of things like what to say to the woman you just had a one-night stand with and the suburbs section is full of things like high schoolers double dating in Mom's car. There's a short quiz after each chapter and a glossary at the end of the book. I believe it also originally came with an audio tape. *** So anyone who wants a wacky non-fictional book or maybe an art book or book on the history of rock 'n roll, please comment to this entry with your address. All comments will be screened (meaning only I will be able to see them) -- I'll unscreen the ones that don't contain addresses.

I posted some stuff about jobs at the other journal: Choices Decision (To summarize: I'm working at a library, a used bookstore, and a lawfirm, adding up to about 35 hours per week. I start at the bookstore and the library next week.) This week I'm covering for Debra, the receptionist at the firm, who is on vacation until next Thursday. It's ridiculously easy money. Their phone barely rings! Half the calls were for Debra! Only C.N. was in the office today. But I did do some transcript summarizing, which -- yeah, it actually is pretty interesting. The firm is on contract for the AFL and was just given the task of organizing the administrative and clerical workers of New York's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. (...the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene! Okay, I'm done.) But according to New York law, managers and those with confidential access to managerial information (personal assistants, eg) aren't allowed to participate in any collective bargaining agreements. So the firm and the city sent out a survey: what's your job title, what is your place within the department, how much money do you make, are you involved in policy creation or decision-making, how many people do you supervise, etc. And then everyone whose survey results came back borderline was called in for further questioning. I got the transcript of the resulting hearings, and my job is to summarize the results in each case, highlighting the factors that would or would not qualify a given person for the legal classification of "manager". ...Okay, so it's mildly interesting. XD Mostly because some of these job descriptions are wild, I didn't know the City was persuing half of these initiatives. Soooo, that's what's been going on over here. (I'm also taking that class at RVCC, but uh. Yesterday we spent two and a half hours learning how to use a microscope. A microscope! And the time before that, we learned that matter is composed of elements. I'm not saying that I don't have mad respect for the nursing students who are 100% serious about passing, I'm just saying, I don't think it's going to be a problem.)

Update on job hunt: After a week of soul-searching I decided that what I really wanted to do this semester was work in a bookstore, but unfortunately this ambition has been tempered by the sad fact that THERE ARE NO BOOKSTORES IN MIDDLESEX COUNTY. ...Okay, I lie. There are the big-box bookstores, Borders and Barnes & Noble, which of course are all off some highway or other. Somerville actually has two used bookstores -- one regular, and one "vintage." (Which is awesome, by the way. Old adventure pulps! Out-of-print science fiction and fantasy! Books-made-into-movies arranged alphabetically by title! Very cool, too bad they're not hiring.) Meanwhile, New Brunswick and Princeton (both University towns) have NJ Books and Rutgers Bookstore, and Princeton Books and the Cloak and Dagger, respectively -- but except for the Cloak and Dagger, a mystery bookstore, these are all textbook/apparel outfits with maaaaaaybe a small general fiction section. Every other independent bookstore in the phonebook went out of business over the summer. When I was in Michigan, I was shocked -- shocked! -- that there was only one highway you could take to head south from Ann Arbor, east from Lansing, etc, because the highway system in New Jersey is triple redundant, but I what I was forgetting was that in most parts of the country, highways are for getting from one place to another, rather than for maximizing shopping space. ^^; Seriously, property values in the "town proper" parts of central New Jersey are so insanely high, they put a real limit on the types of businesses that can afford to do business there. If you're not selling food, clothing, or high-end products, forget it! Everything else is off some highway. (So it's a good thing gas prices are low: $2.65/gallon for regular, compared to $3.15/gallon in Michigan. That's full-service, by the way. I personally think it's somewhat despicable that an an entire culture revolves around driving in circles all night long, supported by low low state gas taxes, but what can you do? It is the Way of Jersey.) Maybe I should stop talking about things I know nothing about. ^^; In any case, I now have applications at Borders, Waldenbooks, Barnes & Noble, Rutgers Bookstore, and Alexander Library. Step two: revisit Book One and the Cloak and Dagger during store hours, apply at knick-knack stores in Highland Park. That said, the test was cool. :p There was only one problem where I was really at a loss: what's sigma of a uniform distribution? Not the formula, the explanation in words. (Sigma is the square root of the variance. But it's a uniform distribution so I was like, what variance?! -_-; I just put down some jargon. "The amount by which a random sample can be expected to deviate from the expected distribution on average." Here, let me translate: "The amount by which" <-- tricky stats talk that avoids any mention of how the numerical amount impacts the distribution, exactly. "a random sample" <-- in hindsight, this was a mistake. Sigma is a parameter variable, that is, it describes the entire population of measurements, rather than a sample drawn from that population (even a random one). "can be expected to deviate from the expected distribution" <-- convoluted way of saying that I know it's a variance, but that the standard definition of variance (average distance from the mean) has no meaning in a case where every distance from the mean is equally probable. "on average" <-- standard-issue stats-speak.) But enough about that! Melinda and Anthony are back in town; I talked them while they loaded Melinda's car. It's possible to produce an unbreakable code using prime numbers. In order for the message to be decoded, the numbers need to line up, like a series of nested wheels whose spokes will only match up when all of the wheels are aligned a certain way. Except that since it's numbers and not wheels, larger numbers can be placed inside smaller numbers, and all of the numbers are changed around constantly. To decode this by force (without a key), you find a common factor by multiplying all of the numbers together. However, if you use sufficient computer power on the original encryption, this kind of solution-by-force becomes actually impossible because it requires more computing power than exists in the world. 4. In the 1980s, a computer company selling encryption software to private security interests (banks, mostly) was instructed by the British government to put some flaws into the design in case it ever fell into enemy hands. 5. Efficient video encoding is accomplished by paying attention to how people view motion, and only bothering to display the parts of the picture they will actually see, allowing the brain to fill in the rest. 6. Television is not efficient because it redraws every pixel or every line, starting from one side of the screen. For the picture to make sense, the "pulses" that cause the lines to redraw themselves much be correctly timed. It's possible to encrypt a television signal by encrypting the pulses in a way such that those with sufficient interest will be able to decode the picture, while those without interest will only see static. Did you know? Mystery series are classified by: 1. setting (place) 2. setting (time) 2. subgenre (romance-mystery, heist-mystery, historical-mystery...) 3. OCCUPATION OF THE DETECTIVE. I totally didn't know this. So if you were looking for a story about a retired librarian/mystery bookstore owner in modern-day Seatle-- well, maybe you wouldn't find it, but you'd at least know whether or not it existed. The most common occuapation was police officer, but there was a really large subcategory for animal detectives. But, alas! Very few students. But I did find out that Victoria Silver wrote a sequel to Death of a Harvard Freshman called...Death of a Radcliff Roomate. ^____^ It's sad to admit this, but when I read the first book in high school, I really thought college was like that. Maybe not the grisly murder part, but the signing up for quirky seminars, buying speed to cram for tests, and never having to go to class parts. Vault of Midnight The only comic-book store on the list. Nothing exciting about this one, just that it was amusing to imagine the crowd of mostly middle-aged women who'd descended on Ann Arbor for the book fair forced into this store. It's in the basement of a shopping complex, you have to walk down a looooong hallway lined with comic book posters and plastic models to get there. I got Kill Me Kiss Me volume 3 (whhhyyyyyyy) and Here is Greenwood volume 6. West End Bookstore A used/rare bookstore minded by an elderly man with glasses held in place by a thin silver chain; there was a notice posted to the shelves titled "How to Properly Open a Book." This store was so intimidating. All of the other customers were at least forty and very well dressed. I tried asking the man-in-glasses if he knew of any uhhh entertainingly written personal narratives from around 1900 edited to showcase "scientific" value, except I said "scientifical" like an idiot. He just looked down at me over his glasses and said I should ask the owner who wasn't in at the moment. Bah. I'm a pretty sloppy-looking person, and ignorant, but that's no reason for... haughtiness, I guess is what it felt like. But wow, great travel section. There is apparently an entire subgenre made up of people who re-trace the journeys of their Victorian ancestors. I bought two books, one on Sicily and one on Ionia. I didn't buy A Tramp's Sketches, but I can tell you it was exactly like what you'd find in a New Age bookstore next to the manuals on Zen and alternative medicine. New Age before there was New Age! Harolds A paper, pattern, and craft book store. I learned that that style, you know, that one that uses ornate gothic fonts and along with half a million curlicues and swirls, bright colors and foil paper with clip art laid over other clip art? Maximalism. Although as far as I can tell that author is the only one using that term in that way. What I didn't do: call my mother back, after I hung up saying I would later (after the bookstores closed). And Sunday was Mother's Day, too. I'm horrible.

There's also been the usual settling in/social scene/lack of computer thing going on -- but the REAL reason I have not been around much recently is that I started playing Suikoden V. Omg soooooo good! I consider myself part of the RPG new-wave, where it all about production values! Production values! And innovation! But Suikoden V is very traditional. The dungeons are linear. The scenery is mostly cut-paste block elements. You play from a 3/4 perspective pulled waaaay away from the characters -- in short, it's ugly! But OMG it's great. I mean, it's olde China AU. You play as a useless Imperial Prince with a snarky/angsty female bodyguard, in an inland nation with a strong river culture. Various things happen, and your family is disposed from the throne. Then it's YOU plus ALLIES vs BAD NOBLE HOUSE ONE (nazis? it's complicated) vs BAD NOBLE HOUSE TWO (sneaky merchant fops). Suikoden V would be perfcet if only: 1) [main character] ran with his sleeves trailing behind him. 2) the text-scrolling was faster or there was a way to skip through it 2) the names were not THE MOST RIDICULOUS FANTASY CLICHES EVER. You know that thing, where you name a character something really weird with lots of Ys and Zs because that's exotic, and try for something that sounds like it would fit the personality of the character without paying attention to whether it sounds anything like the names of your other characters? Arshat for an arhat-looking compassionate queen, Boz Wildes for a big man in a mohawk, names like Sialeeds and Lymsleia for women? Don't do that. Every time a new character is introduced, I laugh and laugh and laugh, because the names are soooooo ridiculous. I have also started on what I am optimistically calling my RPG exercise regimine, meaning that I do all my playing on a bicycle machine I dragged into the living room. You really gain an appreciate for just how much downtime is in these games when you are forced to pedal through all of the load screens, cut-scenes, town exploration, easy random battles...I find it's much easier to resist the urge to talk to everyone in town a second time when every wasted minute is the equivilant of another quarter-mile of uphill cycling.

What do you do for three days in Cincinnati? We killed Friday morning touring the University of Cincinnati which has, like, the most feng shui campus ever. There aren't any quads but there are a million clever little concrete pathways, hidden staircases, and terraced hills. The stadium is sunk into the ground and all the academic buildings are arranged around it, perfectly integrated into the landscape except for this one tower. Mount Adams is the bar/antiques district, and not very exciting on a Friday afternoon. Downtown is Bank Central -- next to our hotel, PNC, GreatAmerican, USBank, and National City. Beyond USBank is Fifth Third bank, the largest (by acreage) in the country. There's almost no riverfront development, so the major downtown attraction is Skywalk, ten department stores and banks (and one hotel) linked by second-floor archways. This is fun in the same way Meijer Madness is fun, ie it is very lame fun. Not that there's anything wrong with lame fun! (I once read an epic quest fantasy that took place entirely indoors. The Hero had to retrieve the Master Keys from the furthest reaches of the House, surmounting various Rooms along the way, each more dangerous than the last!!! For instance, there was one room with jungle-patterned wallpaper where he had to kill a tiger XD.) Saturday we converted the campus-exploratory spirit and my father's nostalgia into an extended Midwest college tour. Miami University in Oxford: brick buildings on quads, student housing with hand-painted ode-to-binge-drinking flags, students are all FBLA-types. Antioch College in Clinton: import knick knacks, new-age coffee shops closed for three hours in the afternoon, students have dyed hair and eyebrow piercings. Along the way we saw the birthplaces of America's Americans John Mellencamp and Sherwin (Sheerwood?) Anderson and were properly respectful of the tomb of President James Henry Harrison, who died of pneumonia three weeks after being sworn into office. Sunday morning was the very excellent Underground Railroad Freedom Center. Highly recommended to anyone interested in dynamic museum design (or, of course, in the history of American slavery). The third floor is slightly schizophrenic, though, with half the floor an information-rich chronology with diverse interests, from emancipation laws to personal narratives to women's rights to Native American rights to the slave-owning histories of the founding fathers, and the other half one of those art gallery SHOCK exhibits, which tries to convince you of current injustices by repeating a montage of five-second news clips ala the aliens in The Abyss. (I'm not saying that there is no "unfreedom" in the world today, I'm saying that this kind of presentation isn't my thing.) Then we were stuck in the airport for hours on end THE END. Completely inadequate description, I know. We were only there for one weekend! And the only person who knew where to go was Dad, and his knowledge was 30 years out of date. Cincinnati did seem like a pretty cool place to live -- just not, you know, like your typical tourist destination.

There'll be no death sentences in California tonight! I've been following this story with increasing amounts of glee. The defense lawyer of the rapist involved is a friend of the family. Basically he got a California district court judge to declare the state's method of execution, lethal injection by non-certified personel, cruel and unusual punishment. The judge's solution was to require a trained anesthesiologist on-hand to assist which, DUH, no respectable medical practitioner will agree to do. In case this sounds like a squirrelly way to avoid Right and Proper justice, you should know that the California death row system is screwed up. The state got so sick of the infinite rounds of appeals -- ala my homestate New jersey, where we have had the death penalty since 1986 and in all that time have managed to execute zero people -- that they went too far in the other direction. New evidence is not grounds to re-try the case of someone on death row unless it is submitted within 60 days of the original trial, sometimes not even then. Verdicts can only be reliably contested on procedural grounds. So basically if you are sentenced to die, all you can do is hire lawyers to stay the date of your execution.
